instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PLT_RESET: What is PLT_RESET? PLT_RESET stands for platform reset. When this is asserted the machine will not POST. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails cycling
threads.message:
Testing on the bench with nothing connected to the board but power.  Can see a slight twitch on the fans at times. Was able to verify that all major power rails are pulsing but present at correct values and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET</SIGNAL>)_L pulses also. 

Resoldered <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> just in case. Tried new BIOS and CLeanME with no change. Liquid indicator was triggered on battery connector but board looks good - a little noticeable residue near the keyboard connector. SMC bypass gets a bit of fan spin but no start.

Thinking maybe GPU bypass, Flux and heat CPU or USC the board... Other thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails cycling
threads.message:
Check if board turns on lifting all GPU coils.
You can also start removing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> resistors, one by one; keep in place <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>.
Just in case, remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails cycling
threads.message:
I had tried the other <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> resistors already but forgot  about <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>. No luck with any of those or pulling the GPU coils.

I'm going to give it a bath and pray.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails cycling
threads.message: This can be marked as solved. USC didn't change anything but being LI were triggered on battery, and my Medusa was unable to program the chip on board, I checked the SPIROM traces and discovered a missing connection from <RESISTOR>R5121</RESISTOR> to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. Board now boots so should be good to go.
